Contrary to popular opinion, homicides....murders...are not a legitimate measure of crime increases or decreases. The fact is, the police cannot do anything to "stop" homicides. You could have 16 cops at an intersection...four on each corner....and a homicide could take place down the block, in an apartment over their heads, or even right in front of them, and there's little they could do to stop it.

The TRUE measure of crime stats is Robberies. They generally happen on the streets at all hours, or in stores where they can be seen from the street. In most cases, the police can formulate plans and strategies to attempt to address Robberies, either with an influx of uniformed cops on the streets, plainclothes cops in the area or, as they did in the late 1960s-early 1970s, put cops in the backrooms of stores in neighborhoods where an increase in Robberies have taken place. Those cops then were armed with shotguns, and when a Robbery was "announced" by an armed perpetrator, the cops would reveal themselves, only to wind up having the suspect's gun pointed in the cop's faces. Needless to say, the police officers took necessary action to prevent themselves from being shot.

But, due to their poor "conviction rate" (the suspect never made it to trial, nor in fact, were they actually arrested), and a somewhat public outcry, the "Stakeout Squad," as it was called, was disbanded.
Because marriage brings expectations about housework and childcare that can be very burdensome to some women.  Those expectations screw up a lot of married relationships.

My friend, Marilyn Silver, came up with a neologism for that unmarried person you've been with, and/or living, as if you were married--"elpee." As in, "I'd like you to meet my elpee." When people ask, you explain it means long-term partner, or L.P. Maybe it takes getting used to this newly coined word, but once your ear does, it makes all the sense in the world and fits the bill quite nicely.

When my partner and I decided we wanted to spend the rest of our lives together, we both realized that we didn't actually want to get married. Both our parent sets are happily married. But we felt like the long cultural history of marriage was part of a religion we don't subscribe to, and the cultural expectations of "wife" and "husband" weren't anything we related to, in stale-but-current cultural jokes, supposed divisions of responsibilities, or elsewhere. The more we looked at it, the stranger it seemed to get married just because we wanted to spend the rest of our lives together. It even seemed potentially disrespectful to both the church, which considers marriage a sanctification, and our gay friends, explicitly barred from marriage themselves.
Our solution was to hold a "welding," a ceremony for friends and family in which we committed to one another for life. Then, with a lawyer, we drew up a legal document affirming all of the legal rights we could confer upon one another: power of attorney, access to bank accounts, etc. Our lawyer used as a model improvised "gay marriages" of times past.
The result has been a happy life as a welded couple, living and working together (we use the term "partner," and don't see what's so cold or dispassionate about it). We miss out on a tax credit, but know fully the terms of our relationship—far better, in fact, than many married couples, who aren't necessarily aware of the complex ramifications of their new legal status.

Juliet said, "What's in a name?  A rose by any other name smells as sweet."  Just say, "This is Bill, or this is Betty."  Friends will know what the relationship is and those who aren't friends don't matter.

Kind of missing the point. There are certain things one cannot change. There are certain things one should not change. There are certain things one can change (like fight a fungal skin condition, maybe--many can only slightly be alleviated), but which won't save you from being unfairly labeled a creep. Regardless, humanity has not moved beyond its knee-jerk reactions when it comes to others, unknowns in any sense of the word, letting the visceral override knowledge and benefit-of-the-doubt--and much pain and isolation ensues thereby.

Mr Rend, I'm so sorry about your feeling "like a creep," and not trying some things that might really help you, such as using an over-the-counter anti-fungal cream on your skin, and using a very strong anti-dandruff shampoo. I'm not nec. predicting that all will return to normal, but your efforts, unless you're allergic to them, are useful. Some people have used fairly cheap Tea-Tree Oil. I know this is a very difficult thing to live with. People usually react to others who are Different in a negative way. They're confused and make negative assumptions.
I used to have VERY blue lips & fingernails, and looked white as a sheet. Even that seemed to bother people. Then when I got a handicap parking placard, the attacks got worse.

I'm sure you're NOT a creep. Working on this miserable problem could really help - and ironically stress & depression probably makes the condition worse! xxx

I write from India. In India, housemaids have to sleep on the floor. They have separate toilets, which are 'Indian' and not the western. They cant sit on a dinning table to eat. They have to eat on the floor. They have to enter the house through the kitchen door. They have to dress shabbily to exhibit the difference between themselves and their master class.

Beyond all this, they are addressed with the pejorative part of the Indian feudal languages, while they have to consistently speak with the respectful part of the word codes about their master class.

The only housemaids who improved in India are those who were housemaids of the colonial folks in British-India before 1947. They learnt English and escaped the social suppression. Moreover in such household, even though they were treated as different, they could sit on chairs and eat from tables. Moreover, English has no feudal pejorative versus respect codes. So their personality also improved.

I have been critical of India and Indian culture in my comments here. But I'm also aware that India is an enormously big and complex country, which some readers---judging from their comments---are not.

So, we have readers wanting to boycott India, by which they mean, not go there as tourists.

They might be interested to know that although India is a poor country (per capita), it is also the world's third largest economy by purchasing power. Most tourism in India is domestic tourism. Foreign tourism makes up a very small percentage of India's GDP, some 17 billion dollars out of 1.85 trillion, in other words, not even 1% of the economy. American tourists comprise 16% of India's foreign tourists. Their annual contribution to India's GDP is therefore one seventh of 1%.

For a country such as India that is about to send a Mars mission, and a Venus probe soon thereafter, believe me, your tourism dollars, in lavishness or in thrift, don't make the slightest bit of difference.
